comments.text:
The spec for this says (at http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css3-background/#border-radius-tables ): The effect of border-radius on internal table elements is undefined in CSS3 Backgrounds and Borders, but may be defined in a future specification. So what is the expected result based on? Note that table row backgrounds aren't actually painted under the row, but rather under its cells. For example, consider this testcase:
Test1
Test2
and note where the green is painted. How exactly would you apply border-radius on the table row to that? Arguably, the fact that the box shadow follows the border radius curve here is a bug in that it's inconsistent with what the background does....
comments.raw_text:
The spec for this says (at http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css3-background/#border-radius-tables ): The effect of border-radius on internal table elements is undefined in CSS3 Backgrounds and Borders, but may be defined in a future specification. So what is the expected result based on? Note that table row backgrounds aren't actually painted under the row, but rather under its cells. For example, consider this testcase:
Test1
Test2
and note where the green is painted. How exactly would you apply border-radius on the table row to that? Arguably, the fact that the box shadow follows the border radius curve here is a bug in that it's inconsistent with what the background does....

Or an even better testcase:
Test1 Test2 Test3
Test4
Again, how would you sanely round the green background bits to any sort of border radius on the row? Note that the background extends out of the row's border box in this case. Also note that while your original testcase has "overflow: hidden" on the row, the spec for 'overflow' says: Applies to: block containers which does not include table-row boxes. So it has no effect whatsoever.
